message_1: In the Trust Game, Player A must decide how much money, x, to send to Player B. The amount sent will be tripled by the experimenter, and Player B will then decide how much of the tripled amount to send back to Player A. If we assume that Player B only sends back half of the tripled amount, how much money should Player A send if they want to maximize their own profit?
message_2:
Let x be the amount of money Player A sends to Player B. The experimenter will triple this amount, so Player B receives 3x. If Player B sends back half of the tripled amount, they will send back (1/2)(3x) = (3/2)x.

To maximize their profit, Player A wants to maximize the difference between the amount they receive back and the amount they initially sent, which can be represented as:

Profit = (3/2)x - x

Simplifying the equation, we get:

Profit = (1/2)x

Since the profit is directly proportional to the amount sent by Player A (x), to maximize their profit, Player A should send as much money as possible to Player B. However, this decision also depends on the trust they have in Player B and the maximum amount they are allowed or willing to send in the game.
